_prev_prog_3.Description: ASV Wines - Peterson has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, ASV Wines - Pond has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 ASV Wines - Pond, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that ASV Wines - Pond has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia                12,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to m

eet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



ASV Wines - Peterson operates a processing facility for wine in McFarland, CA. The facility has four ammonia refrigeration systems that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1

(6) Storage Tanks



Process 2

(1) Wine Chiller



Process 3

(1) Wine Chiller



Process 4

(1) Wine Chiller

(1) Glycol Chiller



The wine and glycol chillers are equipped with shell & tube heat exchangers and accumulators as required for flooded operation. The storage tanks are supplied by a liquid recirculator as required for a pumped overfeed system.



The refrigeration machinery is contained within each outdoor machinery area. A partial list of system components includes:



P1 Machinery Area

(1) Reciprocating compressor

(1) Oil separator

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) Liquid recirculator

(1) Oil pot

(6) Storage tanks



P2 Machinery Area

(1) Screw compressor

(1) Oil separator

(1) Shell and tube wine chiller

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Evaporative condenser



P3 Machinery Area

(1) Screw compressor

(1) Oil separator

(1) Shell and tube wine chiller

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Evaporative condenser



P4 Machinery Area

(1) Screw compressor

(1) Oil separator

(1) Shell and tube wine chiller

(1) Shell and tube glycol chiller

(1) High pressure receiver



Condenser Area

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) Thermosyphon vessel

(1) Diffusion tank (all processes are piped to this diffusion tank)



Process 1 pumped overfeed system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is pipe

d through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each storage tank, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the storage tank.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



Processes 2 thru 4 flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from each high pressure receiver is piped to each heat exchanger where it passes through an expansion valve into a low pressure accumulator vessel.  Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal convection through the heat exchanger.  Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line. The suction line returns the vapor to the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to each high pressure receiver.



Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.

 

Each ammonia refrigeration system at ASV Wines consists of vessels, equipment, and valve which are inter

connected by piping. The systems are located in close proximity to each other and share an ammonia diffusion tank. It is believed that a leak from one system would impact the ability to operate another. Therefore, the ammonia refrigeration systems are treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



ASV Wines - Pond has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the ASV Wines - Pond facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accident History



ASV Wines - Pond has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



ASV Wines - Pond's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Em

ergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



ASV Wines - Pond has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, ASV Wines - Pond continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved ASV Wines - Pond's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that ASV Wines - Pond's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



ASV Wines - Pond has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity in

spection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, ASV Wines - Pond has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, ASV Wines - Pond now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for ASV Wines - Pond employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program ASV Wines - Pond will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
